awd_titl_txt: A Community Building Approach to Preparing Secondary Science and Math Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, the Carthage Noyce Scholarship program will recruit undergraduate majors in biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics and prepare them to become grades 6-12 science and math teachers. This Track 1 Noyce project will fund 26 scholarship recipients over 5 years. In this project, Carthage College in Kenosha, WI will collaborate with high-need middle and high schools in southeast Wisconsin.  Scholars will be recruited into the teaching licensure program with early teaching opportunities through a STEM teaching immersion in the January term and through subsequent seminar classes.  Scholarship recipients will conduct authentic STEM research alongside faculty in Carthage's well-established Summer Undergraduate Research Experience.  This 10-week summer program will also provide an opportunity for scholars to work alongside in-service science and math teachers, who will be invited to participate in an affiliated 4-week research experience. The project will provide mentorship opportunities for scholars before teaching licensure and during their early years of teaching through a community of STEM teaching practice.  Community building activities will include regular task-oriented meetings and summer retreats involving integrated STEM curriculum creation alongside effective and experienced in-service teachers.  


A coalition of STEM and education faculty at Carthage College will implement a distinctive math and science teacher recruitment and preparation program in partnership with secondary schools in Wisconsin. The Carthage Noyce Scholarship program will prioritize early recruitment through immersive, well-supported teaching experiences and will tailor subsequent preparation for successful secondary-level teaching in urban settings through specific coursework as well as targeted clinical experiences in high-need schools.  Exposure to authentic scientific and mathematical research will improve the depth of teacher preparation and provide valuable experience with the interdisciplinary nature of professional-level science and math to pre-service and in-service teachers .  The project will also establish a community of STEM teaching practice wherein networking events, formal mentorship arrangements, and summer retreats develop scholars' professional identity and self-efficacy as teachers. Community of STEM teaching practice events will culminate each year in a summer retreat where scholars and in-service teachers are challenged to collaboratively design interdisciplinary curricula aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards.  Integrated STEM lessons produced by curriculum design retreats will be made widely available as an outcome of the program to enhance curriculum in other high-need STEM classrooms.

por.por_cntn:
The Carthage College Noyce Scholarship program (CNS) provided scholarship support to 24 math or science majors to complete teaching licensure in the states of Wisconsin or Illinois. Scholarship amounts ranged from $16,000 per year early in the program to $22,000 in the final year. In all, the program selected 71% of students who applied for a Noyce scholarship, with an average grade point average of 3.77 for awardees. The 24 awardees represented 92% of the 26 anticipated in the original proposal.

Key elements of the CNS program included:

  1. Targeted recruiting of 1st and 2nd year science majors through authentic classroom teaching experiences in a January Term intensive science teaching class
  2. A community of practice (COP) comprised of scholars and partner teachers from the Kenosha and Racine, WI schools districts that met in person 3 times per yea
  3. An upper level seminar class to provide more specific training and clinical experiences to Noyce scholars nearing licensure
  4. Required and stipended authentic science or math research experiences for Noyce scholars as well as for science teachers in the local school district
  5. Stipended mentor teachers for Noyce scholars in the teaching induction period

In total, 16 CNS scholars followed the undergraduate licensure track and 15 successfully achieved teaching licensure. 8 scholars were awarded funds to complete the Carthage post-baccalaureate accelerate teaching licensure and 7 completed it. Among the 8 who chose the post-baccalaureate route, 4 were recruited through undergraduate programming, 2 were Carthage alumni, and 2 were career changers from elsewhere.

Of the 22 individuals who succesfully completed licensure, student majors were distributed as follows:  7 math, 4 physics, 6 chemistry, and 5 biology. 17 of the 22 identify as female and 5 identify as male. 10 of the 22 have already successfully completed the required teaching service in a high-need school district and 10 are presently teaching in high-need districts. Of the 2 remaining individuals 1 is teaching in a non high-need district, and 1 entered a PhD program in a science.

One of the most distinctive attributes of the CNS was its intentionality about having a broadly interdisciplinary team of science and math investigators. The investigators included a faculty member from each of the targeted departments (Biology, Chemistry, Math, and Physics) as well as from Education. Ultimately, the success of the CNS is rooted in the strong relationships it promoted between the sciences and education faculty and in the improvements it drove in academic advising and recruiting. The investigators feel strongly that this approach is of particular value to Noyce programs at smaller, primarily undergraduate institutions.

Through its COP, the CNS program also developed much closer ties to the local community of science teachers. Although the COP was imagined as being focused on the Noyce scholars, it evolved into a series of professional workshops that had the potential to serve a needed professional development role for newer in-service math and science. The effects of the CNS seenm likely to continue well into the future and deliver lasting benefit to all who have been touched by it. 

 


Last Modified: 12/17/2024
Modified by: Julie Dahlstrom
